verses.text: Very early in the morning, the chief priests, together with the elders, scribes, and the whole council, made a decision. They bound Jesus, led him away, and handed him over to Pilate.
verses.comment: The religious leaders deliver Jesus to the Roman authority. This also fulfills the Psalm about the nations conspiring against the Lord and His Anointed (Psalm 2).

verses.text: Pilate questioned him, 'Are you the King of the Jews?' Jesus replied, 'You say so.'
verses.comment: Jesus’ reply is purposefully indirect. He accepts the title, but not according to Pilate’s expectations. This is a subtle claim to divine kingship, in line with Old Testament prophecy (Daniel 7:13-14).

verses.text: And the chief priests accused him of many things.
verses.comment: The religious leaders present further charges, matching the role of Israel condemning its own Messiah.

verses.text: Pilate questioned him again, 'Have you no answer? See how many charges they bring against you.'
verses.comment: Pilate’s question emphasizes Jesus’ silence before his accusers, fulfilling the prophecy of the Suffering Servant (Isaiah 53:7).

verses.text: But Jesus still made no reply; so Pilate was amazed.
verses.comment: The Messiah’s silence under accusation demonstrates his willing acceptance of suffering and trust in God’s plan.

verses.text: Now at the feast, Pilate used to release for the crowd one prisoner whom they asked for.
verses.comment: This custom gives a choice to the people, symbolizing the offer of choosing the true Messiah or a criminal.

verses.text: There was a man called Barabbas, imprisoned with the rebels who had committed murder in the uprising.
verses.comment: Barabbas (name means 'son of the father') is an ironic substitute for Jesus, the true Son of the Father.

verses.text: The crowd came up and began to ask Pilate to do as he usually did for them.
verses.comment: The crowd is influenced by the leaders, showing the sway of authority and peer pressure in public spiritual life.

verses.text: So Pilate answered them, 'Do you want me to release to you the King of the Jews?'
verses.comment: Pilate’s title affirms Jesus as King, unwittingly proclaiming a profound truth.

verses.text: For he knew it was out of envy that the chief priests had handed Jesus over.
verses.comment: Pilate understands the leaders’ real motives; Jesus suffers not for wrongdoing, but because of envy—fulfilling the experience of the righteous (see Psalm 69:4).

verses.text: But the chief priests stirred up the crowd so that he would release Barabbas instead.
verses.comment: The choice of Barabbas over Jesus highlights humanity’s tendency to prefer worldly solutions and sinful rebellion over true righteousness.

verses.text: Pilate again said to them, 'Then what shall I do with the one you call the King of the Jews?'
verses.comment: Pilate presses the issue of Jesus’ kingship, showing the question of Jesus’ identity as central.

verses.text: They shouted back, 'Crucify him!'
verses.comment: The crowd moves from praise (at Palm Sunday) to rejection, fulfilling what was prophesied (Psalm 118:22).

verses.text: Pilate asked, 'Why? What evil has he done?' But they shouted all the more, 'Crucify him!'
verses.comment: The innocence of Jesus is explicitly stated, emphasizing the injustice and perfect obedience of Christ.

verses.text: Wanting to satisfy the crowd, Pilate released Barabbas to them. After having Jesus flogged, he delivered him to be crucified.
verses.comment: Jesus is treated as the true Suffering Servant. The choice of Barabbas, a guilty man, points to the theological concept of substitution: the innocent suffering for the guilty.

verses.text: The soldiers led him away inside the courtyard (that is, the Praetorium), and they called together the whole cohort.
verses.comment: Jesus is humiliated not only by the religious leaders but also by the state’s representatives.

verses.text: They dressed him in a purple robe, twisted together a crown of thorns, and put it on him.
verses.comment: Purple and the crown of thorns mock Jesus’ kingship, yet reveal him as the true King who suffers for his people.

verses.text: And they began to salute him, 'Hail, King of the Jews!'
verses.comment: Their mockery is ironic; they proclaim the truth of who Jesus is, even unknowingly.

verses.text: They struck his head with a reed, spat on him, and knelt down in mock homage to him.
verses.comment: These abuse fulfill the prophecy of the suffering Messiah. The kneeling, though meant as insult, hints at every knee bowing before the true Lord (Philippians 2:10).

verses.text: After they had mocked him, they took off the purple robe and put his own clothes on him. Then they led him out to crucify him.
verses.comment: Mockery leads directly to crucifixion, showing the world’s rejection of God’s chosen one.

verses.text: They forced a man named Simon of Cyrene, who was passing by, coming from the countryside, the father of Alexander and Rufus, to carry his cross.
verses.comment: Simon represents the discipleship call to take up one’s cross (Mark 8:34). The mention of his sons points to the historicity of the account.

verses.text: They brought him to the place called Golgotha, which means Place of a Skull.
verses.comment: Golgotha links Jesus’ death with the place of Adam’s (the first man’s) skull, according to early Christian tradition—hinting at Jesus as the new Adam restoring humanity (Romans 5:14-19).

verses.text: They tried to give him wine mixed with myrrh, but he did not take it.
verses.comment: Jesus refuses sedation, fully embracing the suffering for salvation's sake.

verses.text: Then they crucified him and divided his clothes, casting lots for them to decide what each would get.
verses.comment: The casting of lots fulfills messianic prophecy, and the crucifixion points to the atoning sacrifice of the true High Priest.

verses.text: It was the third hour when they crucified him.
verses.comment: The 'third hour' (about 9 a.m.) highlights the actual historic time and the public nature of the event.

verses.text: The written charge against him read: 'The King of the Jews.'
verses.comment: The placard over Jesus’ head proclaims his kingship, even as he suffers as the servant king, fulfilling Old Testament hope for a Davidic ruler.

verses.text: They crucified two rebels with him, one on his right and one on his left.
verses.comment: This fulfills prophecy that he was 'numbered with the transgressors.'

verses.text: [And the scripture was fulfilled that says, 'He was numbered with the lawless.']
verses.comment: Some early manuscripts omit this verse, but it resonates with the messianic expectation of the suffering servant.

verses.text: Those who passed by insulted him, shaking their heads and saying, 'Ha! You who would destroy the temple and build it in three days,
verses.comment: The accusation about the temple points to Jesus’ real identity as the new, true temple—his resurrected body.

verses.text: save yourself and come down from the cross!'
verses.comment: This temptation echoes the devil’s challenge in the wilderness (Luke 4:9), but Jesus remains obedient to the Father’s will.

verses.text: In the same way, the chief priests and the scribes mocked him among themselves, saying, 'He saved others; he cannot save himself.
verses.comment: Their mockery unwittingly affirms the truth: Jesus saves others by refusing to save himself.

verses.text: Let the Messiah, the King of Israel, come down now from the cross, so that we may see and believe.' Even those who were crucified with him insulted him.
verses.comment: Ironically, true faith will come only when they understand the reason for his suffering and resurrection.

verses.text: When it was the sixth hour, darkness came over the whole land until the ninth hour.
verses.comment: Darkness symbolizes judgment and the gravity of this moment in salvation history (see Exodus 10:21-22).

verses.text: At the ninth hour Jesus cried out with a loud voice, 'Eloi, Eloi, lama sabachthani?'—which means, 'My God, my God, why have you forsaken me?'
verses.comment: Jesus quotes Psalm 22, expressing profound abandonment, yet also fulfilling prophecy. This can be seen as the high point of his solidarity with human suffering, but does not mean a break in the divine relationship. He is praying the Psalm on behalf of all.

verses.text: Some of those standing by heard him and said, 'Listen, he is calling Elijah.'
verses.comment: There was a Jewish expectation that Elijah would come to help the righteous (see Malachi 4:5), though they misunderstand Jesus' words.

verses.text: Someone ran and filled a sponge with sour wine, put it on a stick, and gave it to him to drink, saying, 'Wait, let us see if Elijah comes to take him down.'
verses.comment: Even as Jesus suffers, prophetic Scriptures are fulfilled. The sour wine recalls the suffering of the righteous.

verses.text: Jesus gave a loud cry and breathed his last.
verses.comment: Jesus’ death is a conscious, willing sacrifice, offering up his spirit. His death fulfills his mission of redemption (Ephesians 5:2), and this moment is the climax of the Paschal mystery.

verses.text: And the curtain of the temple was torn in two, from top to bottom.
verses.comment: The tearing of the temple veil symbolizes the end of the old order and direct access to God through Jesus, the true High Priest and sacrifice.

verses.text: When the centurion, who stood facing him, saw how he died, he said, 'Truly this man was the Son of God.'
verses.comment: A Gentile soldier recognizes Jesus’ divine identity. This is the climax of Mark’s Gospel, affirming the universality of Jesus’ mission and kingship.

verses.text: There were also women watching from a distance, among them Mary Magdalene, Mary the mother of James the younger and of Joses, and Salome.
verses.comment: The women disciples stand faithful, witnessing the passion and later the resurrection. Their presence grounds the account in eyewitness testimony.

verses.text: When he was in Galilee, they used to follow him and serve him. There were also many other women who had come up to Jerusalem with him.
verses.comment: Women as devoted disciples are emphasized, serving Jesus, modeling service as an ongoing reality for the Church throughout history.

verses.text: It was already evening, and since it was the day of Preparation (that is, the day before the Sabbath),
verses.comment: The timing connects Jesus’ death to the Passover, alluding to him as the true Passover Lamb (Exodus 12:6).

verses.text: Joseph of Arimathea, a respected member of the council, who was himself looking for the kingdom of God, took courage and approached Pilate to ask for the body of Jesus.
verses.comment: A member of the council honors Jesus, fulfilling Scripture about the righteous suffering one buried among the rich. Joseph’s courage models reverence for Christ’s body.

verses.text: Pilate was surprised to hear that he was already dead. Summoning the centurion, he asked if Jesus had already died.
verses.comment: The prompt confirmation of Jesus’ death testifies to the historicity of the event, and supports the reality of his full humanity.

verses.text: When he learned from the centurion that Jesus was dead, he gave the body to Joseph.
verses.comment: Even after death, respectful care is given to the body, highlighting the sanctity of the body, which has theological implications for doctrines about resurrection and burial.

verses.text: He bought a linen shroud, took him down, wrapped him in the linen, and laid him in a tomb that had been cut out of rock. Then he rolled a stone against the entrance of the tomb.
verses.comment: The burial fulfills prophecy and prepares for the full reality of the Resurrection. The attention to burial customs demonstrates the continuity between the Old Testament and the New.

verses.text: Mary Magdalene and Mary the mother of Joses saw where he was laid.
verses.comment: Women serve as the first witnesses to Jesus' burial—key evidence for the Resurrection accounts. Their faithful presence hints at the ongoing importance of witness and tradition in the life of the Church.
